title.narrative: WaSH Support to Vulnerable People in North East Syria

description.narrative: On the seventh year from the start of the crisis, the Syrian conflict continues to have severe impact on the civilian population that still requires a humanitarian response to the emergency needs of the most vulnerable. An estimated 6.3 million people in Syria are experiencing acute needs. There are some 2.98 million people living in UN-declared besieged and hard-to-reach areas, of whom almost 420,000 live in UN-declared besieged areas. New displacements have been most frequent in northeast Syria (Ar-Raqqa and Deir Ez-Zor and Hassakah Governorates) with an estimated 300,531 displacements since start of military operation. Displaced people in these areas are living in camps and collective centres in addition to those living in overburdened host communities. IDPs are facing a daily struggle to address their survival needs. Moreover, and while there are more areas that are becoming accessible in the past months, returnees and facing overwhelming humanitarian needs including WaSH, food, non-food items assistance. This Project is aiming to target IDPs, returnees and host communities in differently locations and areas in Hassakah, Raqqa and Deir Ezzour governorates with WaSH assistance. The targeted locations will be camps, overburdened host communities, returnees living in newly accessible areas. In particular, the initiative will complement short-term life-saving assistance (installation of water and and water trucking, distribution of WaSH NFIs, rehabilitation of sanitation systems in camps) with medium-term solutions (maintenance/rehabilitation of water systems), AAH will ensure a comprehensive approach, targeting the same locations and beneficiaries within WASH assistance. A set of activities have been purposely designed to meet the needs of specific vulnerable categories and will prioritize female-headed and those with large number of children. When possible, selection criteria of beneficiaries will consider both PWD and elders, while project monitoring and evaluation will ensure gender impact and collection of disaggregated data. As well, the proposed intervention mainstreams and incorporates protection principles in all activities to promote meaningful access, safety and dignity. AAH will ensure direct implementation of activities through the regular presence of its staff in the field, and strong coordination with project partners, namely the Ministry of Water Resources (MoWR), Syrian Arab Red Crescent (SARC) and other humanitarian stakeholders on the ground.
